application_protocol.purpose: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the exchange of functional data and their schematic representation for process plant. Functional data includes the functional design of systems, and the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.
application_protocol.keywords: application protocol, functional data, schematic representation, process plant, system

li.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the exchange of functional data and their schematic representation for process plant. Functional data includes the functional design of systems, and the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application protocol (AP) for the functional design of systems within a process plant, and for the engineering specifications of system components to be used for subsequent procurement or component design.

purpose.p: With the exception of the schematic representation, the engineering content of this part of ISO 10303 is derived from ISO 15926-2:2003. A subset of ISO 15926-2 has been expressed using the methodology of an ISO 10303 application protocol.

The subset has been chosen to support the exchange of process plant functional data at a particular instant during the life of a process plant. This part of ISO 10303 does not support information about the way in which data has changed during the life of a process plant.
Data defined by this part of ISO 10303 can be merged with other data within a life cycle data repository structured according to ISO 15926-2.
If an ARM entity within an Application Module referenced by this part of ISO 10303, corresponds to an entity in ISO 15926-2, then 0that correspondance is indicated by a note.

li.p: functional data about a physical object within a process plant;
Functional data includes:
A physical object within a process plant can be:

ul.li: a component of a system or of a plant item;
a batch of process or utility material;
a stream of process or utility material.

example.p: Crude oil is a process material.
Cooling water is a utility material.

li.p: Systems within scope include:

ul.li: systems that handle process materials and utility materials;
safety, health and environmental control and monitoring systems;
electrical power generation, transmission and distribution systems with a process plant.

example.p: A lubricating oil system is an auxiliary system for an equipment item.

li.p: Plant items and components within scope include:

ul.li: process equipment (vessels, columns, reactors, pumps, compressors, heat exchangers, boilers, furnaces, storage tanks, etc.), and their auxiliary systems;
instrumentation items (control and safety/relief valves, gauges, thermocouples, etc);
safety health and environmental system hardware (intrusion alarms, site access controls, weigh bridges, fire alarms, building automation systems, HVAC, smoke detectors, sniffers, etc).

li.p: the specification of an activity carried out by a system within a process plant;
A specification of an activity includes:

ul.li: connectivity, where information or material flows from one activity to another;
the involvement of systems, plant items and components, batches and streams of material, people and organisations in an activity.

li.p: Activities within scope include:

example.p: A chemical reaction is a transformation.
A flow through a pipe or wire, or via a conveyor belt, is a transportation.
The heating of a fluid is a change.
The storage of a liquid is a holding activity.

li.p: schematic diagram;
A symbol on a diagram can be linked to a physical object or activity.

note.p: The link between a symbol on a schematic and a physical object or activity makes the schematic 'intelligent'. An application can use this link to support access to data about the physical object or activity by clicking on the symbol.

li.p: Diagrams within scope include:
reference data library;
A reference data library of classes can be used to specify the nature of:

ul.li: an individual document, organisation or person;
a composition or connection relationship between physical objects or activities;
the involvement of a physical object, document, organisation or person in an activity.

note.p: This part of ISO 10303 can be used to store a reference data library of classes. This part of ISO 10303 can also reference to a library of classes. The referenced library of classes can be stored in the format defined by this part of ISO 10303 or any other format which gives each class within the library a unique identifier.

li.p: This part of ISO 10303 can make reference to the reference data library defined by ISO 10303-4. This part of ISO 10303 can also reference a library of standard parts held in accordance with ISO 13582.
person and organisation.
Information about a person or organisation includes:

ul.li: the involvment of a person or organisation in an activity.

li.p: conceptual process design, using process simulators;
simulation or functional testing of systems;
3D shape representation of the plant items, and their spatial configuration in a 3D model;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-227.

li.p: detailed building automation installation information;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-212 and ISO 10303-225.

li.p: detailed physical design of process controls and monitoring systems and of electrotechnical systems;

note.p: This is in the scope of ISO 10303-212. However, the conceptual functional and physical design of process controls and monitoring systems and of electrotechnical systems is also in the scope of this part of ISO 10303.

li.p: information about the plant infrastructure (buildings, steel structures, concrete structures, roads, platforms, ladders, etc);
management and cost information related to procurement and construction;
information related to plant operations and maintenance.

description.p: This overview shows the principal break down of the data into:

ul.li: information about individual products and classes of product;
information about individual activities and classes of activity
information about individual people and organizations and classes of people and organization;
properties of individual products and activities and classes of product and activity;
the presentation of individual products and activity; classes of product and activity; and the relationships between them as an intelligent schematic drawing.

description.p: ISO 10303-1156 specifies an application module for the recording of physical items or products within a process plant. Physical items within the scope of this module are as follows:

li.p: material objects within a process plant;

These include physical assets ranging from major items such as vessel, pumps, pipes and valves to small components within assemblies. The major items will usually have unique asset identifiers, but the small items may not.
functional objects within a process plant;

These include physical objects that are defined by their role, rather than their material realisation. Such functional objects are usually identified by a tag rather than by an asset identifier. These tags may be assigned at an early stage in the design process before any material implementation exists.

Operational activities can be concerned only with the functional objects. For example, the pump with tag P_101 may be operated on Friday and again on Monday, even though the asset that performs the role has been changed over the weekend. To support operational views, it is possible to record both:

ul.li: the functional object with its tag, which persists for long periods during the life of the plant; and
the material object with its asset identifier, which is installed to implement the functional object.

description.p: This module supports the recording of classes of physical item, and the classification of individual physical items. Most of the classes are equally valid for material and functional objects within a process plant. For example, either a functional item with a tag, or a material item with an asset identifier can be classified as a centrifugal pump.
This module supports the recording of composition and connectivity. An individual physical item can be broken down into interconnected sub-assemblies and sub-sub-assemblies as required.

ISO 10303-1169 specifies an application module for the recording of processes or activities carried out by people or equipment within a process plant. The things involved in aan activity, and the role that they play can be specified. A thing involved in an activity can be:

ul.li: an input or output batch of process material;
an equipment item that performs an activity; or
a person or organisation that performs an activity.

description.p: This module supports the recording of classes of activity, and the classification of individual activities. A 'role' is a class of involvement and is defined for a class of activity.

This module supports the recording of composition and connectivity. An individual activity can be broken down into interconnected sub-activities and sub-sub-activities as required. A connection between activities implies a flow of something between them. This can be a flow of process material, energy or information.
ISO 10303-1198 specifies an application module for the recording of properties of physical items and activities. A property can be:

li.p: something that is possessed by an individual product or activity;
This is a classification of the individual product or activity.
something that is necessarily possessed by each member of a class of product or activity.
This is a subclass relationship for the class of product or activity.

description.p: ISO 10303-1203 specifies an application module for the recording of schematic drawing, and for linking the symbols on a schematic drawing to the objects they stand for.

ul.li: P&ID (Piping and Instrumentation Diagram): In a schematic of this type, most symbols stand for physical items. Line symbols usually stand for pipes or cables. These physical items can be either functional objects with tags or material objects with asset identifiers.

PFD (Process Flow Diagram): In a schematic of this type, most symbols stand for processes. Line symbols usually stand for flows between processes. A process is often identified by the tag of the functional object that performs it.

description.p: This module supports the recording of libraries of standard symbols, and the classes of plant item or activity for which a standard symbol might stand.
